content.intro:
Turned towards the future, Oran kept the indescribable charm of sun-drenched Mediterranean cities. Local celebrities such as Yves Saint Laurent or Albert Camus endorsed its lifestyle.

Everyone who has been there knows that Oran is one of Algeria's most beautiful cities. Modern yet attached to its past, the country's second city after Algiers proudly boasts sumptuous monuments, radiant places and most of all, a view onto the Mediterranean beyond compare. El-Bahia “the radiant” holds a never-ending facade onto the sea, that offers freedom and colour-enamoured tourists a wide array of beaches, each more beautiful than the others. And most are accessible to the public...

The word Oran, “Wahran” in Arabic, means “two lions”, those last two having been hunted on the Djebel Kar mountain near Oran. Two statues guard City Hall, and remind people of the episode. According to the legend, wild animals still lived in the area centuries ago. And just like lions approaching close to the suburbs, Oran was subjected to invasions over centuries. Open and cosmopolitan, the city fed on this mingling of cultures.

Of Andalusian, Ottoman and French descent, the city also held an important Jewish community until 1962, when Algeria became independent. Nowadays, even though the Great Synagogue of Oran has become the Abdallah Ibn Salam Mosque, traces of Sephardic culture are to be found a little bit everywhere, especially regarding food (with meatballs, mouna – dome or crown-shaped brioche – and chorba – traditional soup – being choice examples).

The myth of Oran is based on cafés, nightclubs, a relaxed way of life and a free spirit that the city never lost and is envied by many. In the past, people came to listen to singer Reinette el Wahrania, and then to the gods of Raï music, which galvanized the youth, and helped forge its rebellion against authorities, a cultural rallying cry for the entire country. Oranese nights are at the very birth of Raï music. Today, other sounds have emerged from the heart of this ebullient city, ever as lively.

content.title: Fort Santa-Cruz, Oran's historical testimony

introduction.small: Atop Mount Murdjadjo, Fort Santa Cruz was a strategic military base in the 16th century. It enjoys unobstructed views over Oran and its surroundings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fort Santa-Cruz, Oran's historical testimony

paragraphs.text:
From Oran, it is hard to miss this stone giant, carved in the hill and perched 400-metre high atop the Aïdour Mount. Built in the 16th century by the Spanish, Fort Santa Cruz was restored by the French three centuries later. It is now a listed national monument and a testimony of Algerian-French-Spanish history.
To explore the premises, you will have to ride a cable car or drive a very steep road. At the top, open your eyes wide to take in a 360° view of Oran's bay, Mers-El-Kebir's bay and the entire city. You can then climb down below and admire the Santa Cruz chapel and its ivory dome, erected during the outbreak of cholera in the late 19th century. Its statue of the Virgin Mary is a replica of Lyon's Notre-Dame de Fourvière. One piece of advice: visit the fort in the early days of your stay, so you can have a better sense of Oran's spread. In the west, Mers-El-Kebir's port and the military buildings, and the Hassan Pacha mosque in the east. Truly breathtaking!

Fort Santa Cruz
Mount Murdjadjo
31000 Oran

content.title: Ambiance Villa, happiness in a plate

introduction.small: In this small and charming restaurant at the crossroads of European and Algerian cuisines, food is presented in a way that will open up your appetite

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ambiance Villa, happiness in a plate

paragraphs.text:
The newborn of the Ambiance restaurants, which are very popular in Oran and Tlemcen, it welcomes you in a gigantic villa with soft and zen decoration. If you feel like it, start with a cocktail in the colourful flower garden. Time for lunch or dinner? Head to either the indoor dining room or the terrace. Ambiance Villa gathers all the flavours of the sea and traditional local cuisine in a very friendly atmosphere. Its open kitchen allows you to witness the specialities of chef Hafidh Lounas (awarded best chef in Algeria) being prepared under your eyes.
Start with puff pastry-wrapped shrimp and then indulge in the salmon-spinach lasagne. The marinated veal liver is also very popular with regulars. For dessert, the crème brûlée with date honey is a winner. Oh so sweet!

Ambiance Villa

content.title: Cultural evening out at the Théâtre d'Oran

introduction.small: Algerian art is put on the stage and even created at the Théâtre d'Oran, in the heart of the city. The opportunity to discover popular plays full of life.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cultural evening out at the Théâtre d'Oran

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of Oran, on the square of 1 November 1954, stands the Oran Regional Theatre, which was once the city opera. Built in the 20th century in a baroque style, its green and beige facade is enhanced by two small turrets—in the centre, a splendid statue represents the three muses of music, tragedy and comedy—Euterpe, Melpomene and Thalia.

The interior of the building is just as beautiful as the exterior. On the first floor, three stained glass domes illuminate the stairs with an orange light, while in the grand hall, rows of red velvet seats can accommodate just over 600 people.

The theatre has a mission to spread art throughout the region. Since 1968, nearly 70 plays have been created between its walls. This is the perfect place to finish your day with a cultural break before heading out on the town of Oran for dinner at an excellent restaurant.

Théatre Régional d'Oran

content.title: Charme El Cheikh, sense of family

introduction.small: Located in the centre of Oran, this small family-oriented hotel is one of the few that allows you to wander on foot in the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Charme El Cheikh, sense of family

paragraphs.text:
Whether you are in Oran for the first time or after years of absence, you will immediately feel comfortable in this hotel equipped with 66 rooms, including family suites. Every one of them is spacious and well-arranged, and most open onto small private terraces pleasantly dressed with plants.
Would you fancy tea or coffee? Come and feel the spirit of Oran and its pulsating rhythms while organizing your schedule for the following day. Wi-Fi is available in every room and breakfast – which is generous – is included in the room rate. You may also take advantage of the restaurant, which offers international and local cuisine alike. It will give you something to relax to after a long day wandering through the city!

content.title: Le Méridien Oran Hotel && Convention Centre

introduction.small: Nested on high cliff above the Mediterranean between the Mountain of Lions and Fort Santa-Cruz, Le Méridien Oran is much more than just a hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Méridien Oran Hotel && Convention Centre

paragraphs.text:
A few minutes from the city centre, Le Méridien Oran Hotel & Convention Centre enjoys an ideal location to welcome businessmen and city lovers alike. There are 254 rooms and 42 suites available with a refined and contemporary design, restaurants with innovative menus as well as relaxation areas (fitness centre, outdoor swimming pool, hammam, beauty parlour, and a SPA equipped with light therapy rooms to inspire energy and good mood).
Still, Le Méridien Oran Hotel & Convention Centre is not a mere hotel. It is also and foremost the largest convention centre in Northern Africa, with a surface of more than 9,000 m2 of adjustable conference rooms, according to your professional needs.
After an entire day in conference or discovering the beauties of the city, Le Méridien Oran Hotel, nested on top of a cliff, invites for a relaxing stroll in a beautiful garden that overlooks Oran and the Mediterranean. You will love walking down there at dusk while enjoying one of the most beautiful vistas of the region.

content.title: Beauty surrounds Oran

introduction.small: Whether North or South of Oran, take advantage of your stay and visit some of the surrounding areas, especially Kristel, Arzew, Mostaganem and Sidi Bel Abbès.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Beauty surrounds Oran

paragraphs.text:
Located 25 kilometres North-East of Oran, Kristel is a small fishing harbour nested in a cove with a beautiful beach. From there on, you can climb up the 900 metres high Djebel Kristel and enjoy a fantastic scenic view.
A few kilometres down the road, stop at Arzew, known for being a battlefield between allied forces and the Vichy regime in 1942. Take the opportunity and lunch at Gazelles, the famous restaurant of the vicinity that serves a fresh fish refined cuisine all year long and allows you to enjoy a fantastic view on the Mediterranean.
Afterwards, keep up onto Mostaganem. Founded in the 11th century by the Almoravid dynasty, the town remained one of the most Spanish-oriented of all Algeria in spite of the French mark.
South of Oran is also well worth the journey. For instance, go to Sidi Bel Abbès on the banks of the Mekerra river and the Sarno wadi. This town is the birthplace of singer Cheikha Remitti and fighter Marcel Cerdan, and was for a long time the “capital city” of the Foreign Legion. City Hall plaza and its bandstand are full of charm. Visit the small town of Sig very close by, formerly known as Saint-Denis-du-Sig, the Algerian capital of olive products.

content.title: Sheraton Oran Hotel: 5 stars

introduction.small: Only 10 minutes from the international airport and a few steps from the city centre, the Sheraton Hotel overlooks the magnificent Oran bay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sheraton Oran Hotel: 5 stars

paragraphs.text:
Not far from the harbour and the city centre, the Sheraton Oran Hotel inspires respect with a modern facade that gives onto Canastel avenue. As soon as you step in, you will be overwhelmed in an oasis of uniquely designed luxury. Each room offers a very spacious bathroom and a majestic view onto the sea below. For your well-being, the hotel spares no expenses on equipment: a SPA with the latest innovations, hammam, sauna and indoor and outdoor swimming pools.
Regarding culinary delights, you may choose between four restaurants: the Pub and the Atrium Bar offer international cuisine, the Canastel mixes Spanish and North African gastronomies, while Le Ciel d'Oran, up on its 18th floor, invites for savoury fish and seafood in a fabulous setting with a view.
For business travellers, the Sheraton Oran Hotel offers dedicated areas for conferences and banquets, welcoming up to 1,500 people. Each of those spaces gives onto the swimming pool or luxuriant gardens. Whatever the reason of your stay, you will not forget it anytime soon!

Sheraton Oran Hotel

content.title: Fort Santa-Cruz, fortifications with a view

introduction.small: In a typical Spanish style, this fortress was Oran's strategic defence headquarters during Spanish occupation in the 16th century.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fort Santa-Cruz, fortifications with a view

paragraphs.text:
The road that leads to the fort is very pleasant. One suddenly feels like they are in the countryside. Santa-Cruz is located at the height of 400 metres on Mount Murdjadjo. And the view is simply breathtaking. To the East, a vista of Oran. To the West, the Mers-el-Kebir strategic military port. When the sky is clear, it is even possible to see Spain!
Fort Santa-Cruz and, later, the Church that stands close to it were built by Spaniards between 1577 and 1604 to protect Oran from pirate attacks. Several hundred soldiers stayed there and it accommodated the Governor. In spite of the heat, it always feels cool inside. The guardrooms, supply rooms and living quarters can all be visited. Three water tanks, the biggest of them all containing up to 300,000 litres, were used for rain water storage. The whole building is in perfect shape.

content.title: Andalouses beach, blue lagoon

introduction.small: The Algerian coast, and in particular near Oran, is less known than its other Northern African counterparts. Despite being one of the most beautiful along the Mediterranean…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Andalouses beach, blue lagoon

paragraphs.text:
Leaving Oran, you will drive up the coast road along small inlets through nature yet untouched. No resort hotels, no housing estates… just sheer beauty.
The Andalouses beach owes its name to the refugees that landed there when fleeing Spain. Sand is soft, water temperature ideal, and sea sprays melt with the smell of pine trees. Sea bathing there for the first time is absolutely divine.
When feeling hungry, you can drive a little bit further down the road. Cabins and outdoor tables start to pop up and invite you to stop and sit. Slowly but surely, beach restaurants and water sports have appeared, and if you fancy jet skiing or surfing for an afternoon, it is now possible.

content.title: Sidi El Houari, Oran's heart

introduction.small: Sidi El Houari was a Muslim saint. The famous old quarter of the city, equivalent of the casbah, was named after him.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sidi El Houari, Oran's heart

paragraphs.text:
Sidi El Houari is a symbol of Oran, its heart and first city centre, located between the Murdjadjo mountain – also known as Aïdour – and the old harbour. Some of the old Spanish houses date back to the 16th century. Do not miss an afternoon walk there and go through the old Saint-Louis high school, boulevard de Stalingrad and finally the Hassan Basha Mosque.
Long neglected, Sidi El Haouri has become part of the safeguarded sectors of the city in 2015. An old French hospital was the first building to be recently restored, as baths from the roman era were discovered in its midst. For now, restoration works are being supervised by local charities, which lack funding and still cannot renovate the popular houses of the quarter on a bigger scale.

Sidi El Houari quarter

content.title: Le Petit Chalet: sea view

introduction.small: On the coast road between Oran and the village of Kristel, this restaurant sitting on the cliff feels like heaven with an exceptional sea view.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Petit Chalet: sea view

paragraphs.text:
People come to the Petit Chalet for the calm, the scent of pines and the three white terraces overlooking the sea. The house was built in 1926 and has been renovated with great taste in a subtle mix of stone and wrought iron.
Come for a Saturday lunch for instance. If you leave Oran early enough, you will be among the first to be served. It is possible to taste morning fish fresh from the sea, delivered directly to the restaurant by fishermen themselves: sea breams, grilled swordfish and so on, served with large salads and cool water.
In this relaxed atmosphere, everybody takes their time and nothing matters compared to all that blue… Afternoons get on with tea, children are playing and adults shout under the parasols. This is the typical Oranese relaxed way of life.

content.title: Hassan Basha Mosque, Ottoman symbol in Oran

introduction.small: It was built by Baba Hassan Basha of Algiers in 1796 to celebrate the withdrawal of the Spanish. Oran then became Ottoman.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hassan Basha Mosque, Ottoman symbol in Oran

paragraphs.text:
In a way, its history is one of an eternal cycle. After French occupation, the mosque was handed back to the Muslims in 1833. Later on, Napoleon III ordered that it be restored for the first time. Hence the presence of the Emperor's coat of arms on the entrance vaults. In 2007, the American Government made a donation in order to further restore the building. The mosque is in the process of being listed as historical monument.
Octagonal and adorned with earthenware, the thin and delicate minaret rises up like an arrow in the sky. The flat roof is covered in its centre with a large dome surrounded by smaller ones. Does it ring a bell? Once again, byzantine influences are to be felt, Hagia Sophia in Istanbul being the obvious source of inspiration.

Hassan Basha Mosque
Boutkhil
31000 Oran

content.title: Royal Hotel Oran: an institution since 1920

introduction.small: 500 metres from the seafront and the famous Place d'Armes, the Royal Hotel is part of Oran's history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Royal Hotel Oran: an institution since 1920

paragraphs.text:
Completely renovated, this elegant and luxurious hotel foretells what development projects the government plans for the city of Oran. Surely the most precious gem of all Algerian hotels, it displays in the spirit of the MGallery Collection a selection of works by orientalist François Dinet. Known for his portraits of Bou Saâda nude dancers, this 19th century painter converted to Islam and is behind the construction of the Grand Mosque of Paris. He is now considered in Algeria a “national treasure”.
His paintings give the hotel unique charm and atmosphere, as they decorate the 110 rooms, which are perfectly soundproof and answer to international hotel criteria. For a “reverie” of old Oran, do not miss the tea house and bar. You may meet a few ghosts...

Royal Hotel Oran - MGallery Collection

31000 Oran

www.sofitel.com/Oran

content.title: Abdallah Ibn Salem Mosque, Oran's biggest synagogue

introduction.small: After the Independence of Algeria in 1962, the synagogue was turned into a mosque.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Abdallah Ibn Salem Mosque, Oran's biggest synagogue

paragraphs.text:
Oranese Jews settled in the city as soon as 200 A.D. The community didn't lack places of worship but they were too small and too scattered. Rabbi Simon Kanouï took upon himself to build what was going to be the biggest and most beautiful synagogue in all of Northern Africa. It was said construction stones were brought from Jerusalem. Work began in 1879, and the building was opened to the public on May 12th, 1918. It was turned into a mosque after the Independence, declared on July 5th, 1962.
The facade is adorned with two 20-meter-high towers covered with domes. Inside, the three gates mounted with stained-glass panels open onto the nave, which is supported by columns of red marble. You will notice the seal of Solomon on each stained-glass panel, and the teba (platform) is in the oriental style. 900 solid oak chairs are stored on the ground floor. In this space, clearance is overwhelming and breaks for the first time with the Pact of Umar, which specified that synagogues should not be higher than Arab houses.

Abdallah Ibn Salem Mosque
Boulevard Abderahmane Mira
31000 Oran

content.title: Ibn Badis promenade, green stroll in Oran

introduction.small: Formerly known as the Létang Promenade on Oran heights, you will enjoy a stunning view on the harbour and the old town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ibn Badis promenade, green stroll in Oran

paragraphs.text:
It was arranged in 1847 by General Létang who gave it his name, at a time when there were no parks in Oran, as it was not part of the Eastern culture. Spread over 6 hectares, the promenade was set up on small old private pieces of land when Europeans prided themselves on botany and devised green areas wherever they could. It is now considered the oldest park in all Maghreb.
If the area evolved through time, landscape gardeners never ceased maintaining it. New species were introduced, including rare varieties like fig trees, aloes and palm trees. Oranese people are extremely fond of this heritage and renamed the promenade their “love garden”.
You will not only enjoy a very pleasant stroll, but also possibly other modern events, as the city now organises music festivals and numerous outdoor plays and readings.

Promenade Ibn Badis
Cable MT-1 Sidar
Oran

content.title: La Comète: just like home

introduction.small: Concentrate on your plate, just enjoy!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Comète: just like home

paragraphs.text:
It is a fact, the 80's kitsch design is not the selling point of this restaurant, which always seems closed from the outside with curtains drawn. Yet, not only is it actually open, but it is always packed!
Fish is always perfectly cooked. Note that this is one of the few restaurants in Oran where fish soups are served with rouille. However, the chef's special is the shish kebab, large exquisite and tender piece of lamb on a skewer. Or brains à la meunière, a fine dish that has become too rare…
On Friday, it is couscous day, and what a treat! A large selection of wine is available, so why not fall for a nice country rosé? And desserts are first-rate. In season, try Algerian strawberries, sweet and perfumed. Caramel cream is also a safe bet. And so is the apple pie…

La Comète
1, rue de la Paix
31000 Oran

+213 41 29 45 84

content.title: Bey's Palace, home of the Princes

introduction.small: Oranese people call it “Château Neuf” (New Castle). This is where Bey Muhammad el-Kebir moved his residence when he took the city back from the Spaniards.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bey's Palace, home of the Princes

paragraphs.text:
Strategically located, the palace is built on a promontory above town and overlooks both the harbour and hinterland. It always provoked envy, and in 1514, the Spaniards built a first building they named “Bordj Lahmar”. Extended, it was renamed “Rozalcazar”. The current wall was erected during that second rule, and tunnels were dug.
The bey moved his residence within those walls because they survived the 1790 earthquake that destroyed a major part of the city. A second palace was then built next to it, where he had his apartments and offices, as well as the pavilion of the Favourite Concubine, supplemented with two beautiful pleasure gardens and an aviary. Walls were dressed with earthenware, chandeliers were designed in openwork copper and all woodworks were sculpted.
Listed in 2005 as national heritage, this outstanding architectural and archeological ensemble sums up seven centuries of history by itself. It amply deserves your attention in spite of its current condition (renovation work is intended section by section over the years). After your visit, stroll down to the Ibn Badis Promenade right underneath!

Bey's Palace
Rue Meftah Kouider
31000 Oran

content.title: Four Points by Sheraton: luxury liner onto the sea

introduction.small: In this international hotel, you will feel like on a cruise. The view onto the Mediterranean is stupendous.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Four Points by Sheraton: luxury liner onto the sea

paragraphs.text:
Oran's shades of white and blue colours are unique, and really distinctive of the bay, where the sea and the sky meet and marry each day. Comfortably sitting in a deckchair by the swimming pool, you will find yourself contemplating the incredible view, and start philosophising about its beauty.
This contemporary hotel whose interior design marries the seascape has been strategically built to offer a stupendous experience for all customers. Rooms are spacious – so are the bathrooms – and give the impression to glide across the waters. Mist comes from the sea at dawn, whereas the setting sun burns through the waves at the end of the day.
Add to it a high quality restaurant and a pleasant lounge café and everything is set for a romantic stay, or a business travel on high-end performance.

Four Points by Sheraton Oran

content.title: Hotel Colombe, a private hotel

introduction.small: If you go to Oran for professional reasons, you will love this small hotel of Art Deco inspiration, part of the Best Western group.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Colombe, a private hotel

paragraphs.text:
When you get there, just have a look at the guest book: you will read only compliments. And sincere ones, that is... This small hotel of 23 rooms wins unanimous support with the clientele for the quality of service and performances. Only two minutes away from the city centre and ten minutes from the airport, it subtly combines tradition and comfort. You will feel the charm of Oran without ever feeling disoriented.
If you go there as a family or couple, choose one of the three suites. You will feel just like at home. But the real bonus in this hotel is the personnel that serve you. From reception hall to room service and restaurant, you experience an all-time attentive service that will help you make the best of your stay. Which you are to remember only fond memories of... ready to be, in turn, inscribed in the guest book.

content.title: Ahmed Zabana National Museum, learned society

introduction.small: Algeria is the cradle of ancient civilisations. Hence the idea of dedicating a museum to roman and African antiques, numismatic and paintings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ahmed Zabana National Museum, learned society

paragraphs.text:
Passion in archaeology goes back to the 1830's and was as present in Algeria as it was in the rest of the Middle-East. This museum was born out of the will of archaeologist Louis Demaeght (1831-1898) to collect in a same place all items discovered in local archaeological digs. It is thus possible to admire two splendid mosaic works from the “old Arzew” site, depicting Bacchus leaving for East Indies.
At the same time, the museum devotes some sections to painting. It is possible to relish some of the masterpieces from the École d'Alger movement which developed in the interwar period, including works by Jean Launois, Léon Cauvy and Paul Émile Dubois. Contemporary Algerian art is given prominence, as remarkable local artists' works cover a period of time, running from the early 20th century to the present day, vouching for the artistic vitality of the country.

Ahmed Zabana National Museum
19, boulevard Zabana
31000 Oran

+213 696 18 64 75

content.title: Le Corsaire: kitchen of a fisherman

introduction.small: Fish, more fish, and only fish! Nothing really surprising since this little restaurant belongs to a fisherman.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Corsaire: kitchen of a fisherman

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of Sidi el-Houari and close to the fishery, this is one of Oran's most notorious restaurants. The owner, Mister Nacer, will never be found at fault regarding the quality of the fish he serves. Le Corsaire is known and renowned for the quality of the menu.
Speaking of which, you will find fish soups, crustacean boureks (rolled brik pastry sheet specialties), red mullet, swordfish, and calamari with cuttlefish ink sauce… Last but not least, the Algerian main specialties: stuffed sardines and the inescapable paella, more present than couscous on restaurant menus, probably due to the Spanish influence…

Le Corsaire

content.title: The Cathédrale du Sacré-Cœur, now Oran's public library

introduction.small: Since 1996, this cathedral has become Oran's central public library.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Cathédrale du Sacré-Cœur, now Oran's public library

paragraphs.text:
Go back in time to the end of the 19th century. The French population that colonised Oran keeps growing and the clergy feels the city does not have enough places of worship. Oran's bishop, His Grace Monseigneur Cantel decides to build a second cathedral. In order to do so, he took up his pilgrim's staff and went to France to raise funds.
Construction work began in 1904 and ended in 1913. The architect's plans were modified several times and adapted as a colonial counterpart to metropolitan models. If the building is blessed in 1930, it does not include its altar, which was built in reinforced concrete, a material not recognized by canon law. However, this detail also built its reputation: the Cathédrale du Sacré-Cœur was at the time the first to use reinforced concrete on French territory.
Today, it has become Oran's public library and welcomes numerous Oranese students each day.

Cathédrale du Sacré-Cœur
Boulevard Hammou Bou Tlélis
Place de la Kahina
31000 Oran

content.title: El Mouahidine: ideal for business travellers

introduction.small: Located close to the airport, this hotel is recommended to business travellers and those under a tight schedule, for it combines comfort and convenience.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: El Mouahidine: ideal for business travellers

paragraphs.text:
If you fancy 100% design boutique hotels, count on the El Mouahidine Hotel. Two minutes away from Oran's international airport, it is an ideal solution for those who want to explore the city, even more so if you plan to come to Oran on business.
This is a modern hotel, fitted with a nice outdoor swimming pool if you want to relax after a business meeting. It is equipped with all required services for “connected people”: LCD screens, Hi-Fi, Wi-Fi... Rooms are spacious and perfectly soundproofed, and bedding of high quality. Should you have meetings, assemblies to be organised or places to visit, the hotel offers a selection of privatised rooms and vehicles. You may also enjoy a lot of other services such as a quality restaurant, a SPA and tennis courts.

El Mouahidine Hotel

content.title: Le Méditerranéen: no fish is left out

introduction.small: Famous around Oranese people, the menu offers fish in a brasserie style.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Méditerranéen: no fish is left out

paragraphs.text:
On the menu, you will find lobster Thermidor, ray with beurre noir or mussels with cream. These dishes are part of the French brasserie culture, but it is possible you may be tempted, under Oran's blue sky, by a paella valenciana – Spain is not that far away – or by a local specialty like salt-baked or couscous grouper. That fish, plentiful on this side of the Mediterranean, is the star of the restaurant alongside gilthead bream, sole and whiting. They are always perfectly cooked and prepared. Remember to book a table on the terrace so as to enjoy the swimming pool afterwards.

content.title: Le Cintra, mythical Oranese brasserie

introduction.small: Writer Albert Camus, architect Fernand Pouillon and many other intellectuals had habits in this restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Cintra, mythical Oranese brasserie

paragraphs.text:
This brasserie with a typically Parisian feel is a reference in Oran. It reopened two years ago after renovation works, but keeps an unmistakable retro brasserie character. With a combination of red velvet wall hangings, deep sofas and woodworks, Le Cintra develops a certain high-end spirit.
The menu was once 100% Parisian, but has opened up to Mediterranean cuisine. Indulge in the sautéed veal with mash, foie gras, fish soups, grilled sea bass, and even salade niçoise, prepared according to the standards of the original recipe and served with anchovies!
In this restaurant opened round-the-clock, excellent Algerian and Spanish wines are also available. However, the best times to enjoy the place are at lunchtime, or for early dinner, before going deeper into the night to discover another side of Oran.

Le Cintra
14, boulevard de la Soummam
31000 Oran

+213 560 00 03 46

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Oran
content.introduction: Oran is a coastal city that enjoys a typically Mediterranean climate. Summers, from June to September, are usually very hot. Winters, from December to March, are cool. Spring (April/May/June) and Autumn (October/November), with mild weather are the best seasons to visit Algeria's second largest city.

airports.title: Oran Ahmed Ben Bella Airport
airports.description:
The Ahmed Ben Bella International airport is 12 kilometres (7 miles) south of Oran.
  • One terminal (T1): Air France

A second terminal is under construction, for a summer 2019 opening.

Travelling between the airport and Oran:
  • By car
    Directions: Downtown Oran is 20 minutes away from the airport when using the N2A road.
    There is a parking lot with a capacity of 900 in the immediate vicinity of the airport. Entrance ticket is DZD 60 no matter the duration.
    Several car rental companies are located in the arrivals hall.
  • Hotel shuttles
    Some hotels organize their own shuttles from the airport. Check with your hotel ahead of time.
  • Taxis: Taxis are available at the ranks when exiting the airport. Price must be negotiated beforehand. Allow around DZD 400 for a trip downtown.
  • Services :shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi), bank, mailboxes and prayer rooms available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +213 41 59 10 77
  • *Website: http://lesaeroportsdoran.dz/

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Oran
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Oran each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: Third month of the Hijri calendar: Eid Al-mawlid an-Nabawi (national)
events.description: The birth of the Prophet Muhammad is celebrated each year in Algeria. Prayers and celebrations during these two days make them a family-holiday.

events.title: March 20: International Francophonie Day (national)
events.description: 49 French-language speaking countries including Algeria celebrate their link with France. Poetry and writing contests are held for the youth, as well as meals and games about French culture and language for everyone.

events.title: May 1: Labour Day (national)
events.description: Labour Day is a public holiday for all Algerians. This day is spent on parades and worker marches.

events.title: Ninth month of the Hijri calendar:Ramadan (national)
events.description: The Islamic holy month of Ramadan, during which the Quran was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad, is an especially pious time in Algeria, a country with a majority Muslim population. Fasting begins each day at sunrise and ends at sunset. For the entire month, Oran operates at a slower pace during the day and stirs into action at nightfall.

events.title: First day of Chawwal (date set according to the Hijri calendar): Eid al-Fitr (national)
events.description: In Islam, this day marks the end of the fasting month of Ramadan and is a time for celebrations with family and friends.

events.title: July 5: Independence Day (national)
events.description: This holiday commemorates the Independence of Algeria as proclaimed on July 5<sup>th</sup>, 1962 by General de Gaulle. It is an opportunity for many official speeches, parades and popular rejoicing.

events.title: July 19: Righting Day (national)
events.description: The Anniversary of the Algerian coup d'état of June 19<sup>th</sup>, 1965 which saw Houari Boumédiène take over as president is cause for yearly celebration.

events.title: Tenth day of Dhu al-Hijjah (date set according to the Hijri calendar): Eid al-Adha (national)
events.description: It is considered the most important of the yearly Muslim holidays and honours Ibrahim as a model for all believers. This is also an occasion for sumptuous family gatherings, for which it is recommended to multiply offerings and gifts.

events.title: November 1: Anniversary of the Revolution (national)
events.description: November 1<sup>st</sup>, 1954 is the official starting point of the war between France and Algeria. This event is cause for yearly celebrations, official memorial services and political speeches.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Algeria
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you need to obtain a visa if you will be staying in Algeria. The request should be addressed to the Algerian consulate.

To travel serenely in Oran and Algeria, follow the travel advice of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs:

https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/algeria/

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime: No Daylight Savings Time in Algeria.
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping

Tipping is not necessarily required, although always appreciated if you are satisfied with the service. You may leave a tip in restaurants and hotels, for 10 to 15% of the bill.
